stem: An 88-year-old female is admitted with a new-onset of extreme lethargy, 'depression,' and loss of appetite. Based on the documentation in the Geriatric Endocrine & Cognitive Status Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Assessment for sub-acute metabolic crisis in an elderly client.
Background: History of Graves' disease (diagnosed 20 years ago). Lapsed follow-up.
Assessment: Client is slumped in her chair, appearing 'zombie-like' and weak.
Recommendation: Immediate thyroid panel and cardiac rhythm check.

tabs.title: Geriatric Endocrine Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Serum TSH< 0.01 (Critically Low)Extreme Hyperthyroidism
Mental StatusApathetic; Dull; DepressedParadoxical CNS Response
Weight10 lb loss in 2 weeksHypermetabolic state
Heart RhythmAtrial Fibrillation w/ RVRHR 138 bpm

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 158/92, HR 138, RR 24, T 100.2°F (Mildly high for aged). SpO2 94%.

actionOptions.text: Administer IV Propranolol to control the heart rate
Establish continuous cardiac monitoring to assess for AFib
Provide high-flow warm blankets to treat lethargy

parameterOptions.text: Cardiac rhythm and frequency/duration of tachycardia
Level of consciousness and nutritional intake
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Geriatric Apathetic Thyroid Storm (c2). Unlike younger patients who present with agitation and 'fire,' elderly patients often show 'apathy'—meaning they are lethargic, depressed-looking, and physically weak. However, the thyroid labs (TSH <0.01) and heart rhythm (AFib/Tachycardia) confirm a hypermetabolic crisis. Priority actions involve managing the heart with beta-blockers (a1) and continuous EKG monitoring (a2). Key parameters: Cardiac stability (p1) and monitoring for further mental decline (p2).
clinicalPearls: Apathetic thyroid storm is a high-mortality killer because the symptoms (lethargy, weight loss) are often mistaken for 'just getting old' or cancer.
The only 'classic' hyperthyroid sign usually seen is the persistent tachycardia or Atrial Fibrillation.
Propranolol is still the treatment of choice to block T4 to T3 conversion.

questionTrap.trap: Treating this as Myxedema Coma because the patient is 'lethargic'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Look at the heart rate! Myxedema (Hypothyroid) causes Bradycardia (<60). Thyroid Storm (including apathetic) causes Tachycardia (>100) or AFib. The heart rate reveals the true metabolism.

mnemonic.title: Old Storm Cold
mnemonic.expansion: Patient looks SAD, but the T3/T4 is MAD (High). HR is fast, it's a thyroid blast.
